discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
vSphere
Less than 150 ms latency RTT for vCenter Server connectivity.
Less than 150 ms latency RTT for vMotion connectivity.
Less than 5 ms latency RTT for VSAN hosts connectivity.
vSAN

Less than 200 ms latency RTT for up to 10 hosts per site.
Less than 100 ms latency RTT for 11-15 hosts per site.
NSX Managers

Less than 10 ms latency RTT between NSX Managers
Less than 150 ms latency RTT between NSX Managers and transport nodes.

Selected Answer: AB
That can be the only right combinations of Answers. In Stretched Cluster we need a third site for Witness

A. There must be separate Network Pools for each Availability Zone.
B. A third site is required for a witness host.

questions.question_text: Which two components are required when planning for stretched clusters in a VMware Cloud Foundation environment? (Choose two.)

choices.E: The round-trip time (RTT) between sites must be ≤ 15 milliseconds.
choices.C: The host overlay network can use static IP addresses.
choices.A: There must be separate Network Pools for each Availability Zone.
choices.B: A third site is required for a witness host.
choices.D: Use shared vSphere vMotion, vSAN, and host overlay networks.

questions.question_text:
An architect is designing networking for a developer-ready infrastructure on VMware Cloud Foundation.

Which use case would require the architect to consider a CIDR range larger than /27 for Egress?

discussion.content:
D is correct
Ingress and egress networks allow external workloads to communicate with vSphere pods.
Ingress and egress networks have the following characteristics:
• They are routed and advertised to external networks through the Tier-0 router.
• A /27 CIDR range or higher is the best practice.
• One egress IP address is assigned to each segment.
• One ingress IP address is assigned to each deployment of type ingress or load balancer.

Because the ingress and egress networks are externally accessible, you must carefully consider the size of the CIDR range that you require for each network type. If your ingress subnet is too small, you limit the number of ingress and load balancer services that you can deploy in the cluster. If your egress subnet is too small, you limit the number of segments or namespaces that you can deploy.

From VMware Cloud Foundation: Deploy, Configure, Manage [V5.0]

Selected Answer: D
There would be one Egress per vSphere Namespace created, irrespective of the number of TKC clusters/pods created it that namespace

Selected Answer: D
i Think EvilRobs answer is right....the limitation is one ip pro namespace.

comments.content:
D. Only one egress IP address is assigned for each namespace in the Supervisor. The egress IP is the address that external entities use to communicate with the services in the namespace. The number of egress IP addresses limits the number of egress policies the Supervisor can have.
The minimum is a CIDR of /27 or more. For example, 10.174.4.96/27

Shouldn't it be D per that same link?

"Only one egress IP address is assigned for each namespace in the Supervisor Cluster."

discussion.content:
A. More than 30 services are required
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-B1388E77-2EEC-41E2-8681-5AE549D50C77.html

questions.question_text:
VCF design workshops have been conducted, and the architect collected the following customer requirements for the newly planned VCF infrastructure:

• The new VCF infrastructure is targeting two zones: DEV/UAT and DMZ.
• The infrastructure team requested that the number of management components be minimized as much as possible.
• Eight hosts should be ordered for the DEV/UAT environment.
• Four hosts should be ordered for the DMZ environment.
• The DEV/UAT workloads must comply with an erasure coding vSAN storage policy and have the ability to tolerate the failure of two hosts.

Which workload domain sizing will be required to achieve these requirements?

discussion.content:
The answer in this case should be A.

This question is similar to question 45. However, there we had the requirement of isolation between zones. So, in that case, the answer should be B. But here instead of that, we have "The infrastructure team requested that the number of management components be minimized as much as possible" then the answer is A.

Selected Answer: A
Only one wld Domain - min. Mgmt compoments
They are targeting 2 zones, so wouldn't (B) be the correct answer? You need 6 hosts for a FTT of 2 hosts - so C and D would be incorrect. I am going with B

Selected Answer: A
B would not meet the requirement of minimizing management components...

choices.C: 8-hosts DEV/UAT workload domain, having a 4-hosts DEV cluster, and a 4-hosts UAT cluster, in addition to a 4-hosts DMZ workload domain, having a 4-hosts DMZ cluster
choices.A: 12-hosts workload domain for both zones, having an 8-hosts DEV/UAT cluster, and a 4-hosts DMZ cluster
choices.D: 12-hosts workload domain for both zones, having a 4-hosts DEV cluster, a 4-hosts UAT cluster, and a 4-hosts DMZ cluster
choices.B: 8-hosts DEV/UAT workload domain, having an 8-hosts DEV/UAT cluster, and a 4-hosts DMZ workload domain, having a 4-hosts DMZ cluster

choices.D: Minimum of three hosts using NFS, VMFS on FC, or vVols as a principal storage
choices.A: Minimum of three hosts using vSAN as a principal storage
choices.E: A new vCenter license to accommodate the additional cluster
choices.C: All hosts in maintenance mode with no patches applied
choices.F: Minimum of five hosts for any type of principal storage
choices.B: Valid license specified in SDDC Manager
